(00:11)And I was thinking about connection and listening to the song "Hammond Song "by the Roaches, which is kind of a polarizing song. Some people love it; some people think it's kind of annoying. But recently listening to it with Soren, who also really likes it, but also Victor, who doesn't like it at all—it's just something about that dynamic—sharing the experience of enjoying a song, but also sharing the joke of the other person in the room who doesn't actually like it.

label: mutuality
def: mu·​tu·​al·​i·​ty // the state or quality of possessing the same feelings one for the other
pullout: After all of the difficulties we had and the intensity of the race, I felt a new level of mutual support.
transcript:
(00:00)A memory from a moment of deep connection I have is one of a 30-mile-adventure run through the mountains, combining biking and hiking.

And the connection that time was twofold. One was more personal. It was an inner connection that you feel after hours of physical activity. And in that moment when you can only think about breathing and moving your legs and not more than that, but you're fighting, as well, with a little voice asking you to quit and stop the suffering. So this is a kind of connection that is not a peaceful one, where you feel like meditating, but more like a dynamic one and also embedded with adrenaline. It's a different kind of connection, but very intense as well. (00:54)On the other hand, I had like a more interpersonal connection because it was a pairs race and I ran it with my brother. Well, after all the difficulties we had and the intensity of the race, I felt like a new level of mutual support. And the biggest example of this was at the end of the race, in which, after puncturing the wheels of my bike many times, we could not repair it anymore. So we had to finish as two together, mounting only one bike. And we crossed the finish line that way, cheered by the public that applauded and shouted. That's like really in nice memories.

label: nature
def: na·ture // the external world in its entirety
pullout: I spend entire days observing nature, the gradual calming of nature. Every place here is a friend I am happy to see again. And somehow places I am not familiar with become my property.
digtxt: Fleur Jaeggy’s Mourning Exercise: On the rain-soaked tribute of The Water Statues ," an article published in The Baffler
transcript: (00:00)Though the years vanish as swiftly as ever, sorrow and life coming to an end make time seem too long. I spend entire days observing nature, the gradual calming of nature. And sometimes my ideas become vague, undecided. Without tiring them, a wild sadness rests in my eyes and my gaze wanders over the rocks all around. Every place here is a friend I am happy to see again. And somehow places I am not familiar with become my property. (00:32)There is one spot there, high on the field from which the limestone humps descend and ceremoniously and lethargically down the water. And it's as though a fact recollection were telling me that I'd lived there or in the water long ago, that the exact trace of that time has been erased in me.

label: normalcy
def: nor·​mal·​cy // that which is considered usual, typical, or routine
pullout: It's like everything is normal again.
transcript: (00:00)I feel connected when you have long distance friendships and haven't seen them in so long. But when you do see each other, it's like everything is normal again.

label: nuance
def: nu·​ance // sensibility to, awareness of, or ability to express delicate shadings
pullout: At the end of the day, we're all just goofballs.
transcript: (00:00)On Friday, when we were in type class, super tired from the week, you know, making a bunch of shit to show even though we didn't like it, and just sitting around joking about our own column usage when setting a layout and how we'll create ten columns and not even use all of the columns. It's just a really nuanced design joke that—I never really made jokes like that with a lot of my friends from high school or even college. (00:30)And it kind of just summarizes the feeling of going to grad school and finding your people and finding humor in the things that we all take super seriously. But at the end of the day, we're all goofballs.

label: place
def: place // a distinct environment, condition, position, or state of mind
pullout: A place belongs forever to whoever claims it hardest.
transcript: (00:00)"A place belongs forever to whoever claims it hardest, remembers it most obsessively, wrenches it from itself, shapes it, renders it, loves it so radically that he remakes it in his own image.

label: play
def: play // brisk, fitful, or light movement
pullout: My inner child was gone. I didn't want to play. I didn't want to have fun. Fun was gone for me.
transcript: (00:00)Basically, I got pregnant when I was, like, 23. So I was really young, and it wasn't like a planned pregnancy or anything like that. And it was really hard for me to accept the pregnancy throughout the whole thing. I literally just stayed home and, like, hid from people. I barely even told anyone I was pregnant. And then the day before my daughter was born, my dad passed, so that was really hard and after my daughter was born. I entered into this weird—not depression—I don't know what it was. I was just like, I don't want to do anything. But I had to because I had a child. I had to wake up early in the morning. I had to stay awake during the night to feed her. (00:38)So throughout the years, I noticed I kind of lost myself in a way. Generally, I've always been, like, a very playful person. My inner child was gone. I didn't want to play. I didn't want to have fun. Fun was gone for me. So until a year ago, because she's now one, I remember I hated having to play all the time. I didn't enjoy it. (01:01)So more or less a month ago, I was coming back home with my daughter, and it was raining, and she starts jumping in the puddles and wetting all her feet, her pants. All wet. And my initial reaction was like, Oh, no, no, we have to go. We have to go. Let's not get wet. But then I stayed there for a second, and I watched her, and I was like, Oh, my God. I remember how fun this was when I was a kid. And then I was like, Wait, actually, no, we don't have to go. We can stay. And I started jumping in the puddles with her, and she was laughing so much. And that's a time that makes me think of what it means to be connected. And I felt like my inner child was finally coming out again. Because I realized, Oh, I didn't lose my inner child. Like, it's still there. I'm still me. I just needed time. And now it's just so much better.

label: proximity
def: prox·​im·​i·​ty // the quality or state of being very near to something
pullout: To be thousands of miles away but still feel held and in proximity, to the people and places I grew up with and love so dearly, was truly special to find where I did.
transcript:
For me, when I think of the word ‘belonging’, I think of people. Growing up in a small town, it’s always been the people that I feel connected to, that make my small Vermont town, (or Vermont as a whole) so special and give me a sense of belonging.

And I never expected to find that sense of connection and belonging that comes with my small Vermont town(s), all the way out in Utah. But from the moment I moved here 8 years ago, the connections were everywhere. So-and-so grew up with my cousins, so-and-so is the brother of someone I went to elementary school with, so-and-so is my best childhood friend’s aunt. The large majority of these connections are through the ski community, where New Englanders flock to Utah to live or visit to ski. And working at the ski resort I ran into these people seemingly everyday—the people who’d see my last name on my name tag at work at the mountain and tell me they just saw my dad last week cause they brought their dog to the vet. Or the brother of my parents' carpenter friend who informed me my parents were building a porch (to which I told him they’d been saying that since 1990 and I didn’t believe him).

These intimate connections that touch my heart were everywhere in Utah, and it instantly felt like home, because my homem was still surrounding me. I could still feel the place and people I identify with and hold so close to my heart, in a place that looked a lot different, but made it easy to settle in and feel like I belonged here too.

To be thousands of miles away but still feel held and in proximity, whether it was only emotionally or otherwise, to the people and places I grew up with and love so dearly, was truly special to find where I did.

label: reality
def: re·​al·​i·​ty // something that is neither derivative nor dependent but exists necessarily
pullout: The memories were real. Everything was real.
digtxt: Confession i the character" by Hurt/Comfort
transcript: (00:00) "The memories were real. Everything was real. And if I closed my eyes long enough, you were real too. I'm just an idea. But an idea can consume you.

label: references
def: ref·​er·​ences // something that refers or alludes to another source of information
pullout: It made me think of the interconnected ways that we all understand certain cultural reference points.
transcript: (00:00) So yesterday I went to vote, and I had to go to where I grew up and where my parents still live. And I walked into this small town town hall and they're playing "Never Gonna Give You Up," by Rick Astley as I'm getting my ballot, which is just like, really funny. (00:15) And I guess, as these things often do, it just made me think of memes and the interconnected ways that we all understand sort of cultural reference points. And like "Never Going to Give You Up" being like a "Rick Roll" as like a fooled-you, got-you, light-hearted internet prank just has like this deep irony to me as I'm voting.

label: reflexivity
def: re·​flex·​iv·​ity // of, relating to, characterized by, or being a relation that exists between an entity and itself
pullout: When we really listen and support one another and share with each other, we begin to see a little of those people in ourselves and a little of who we are reflected back to us in them.
transcript:
(00:00)The quote that comes to mind when I think about belonging is from one of the texts that we use in recovery. And it says, "We began to see a little of us in them and a little of them in us."

And I really like that quote because I think I'm constantly thinking of myself as the exception, like, Oh, I'm the one no one is gonna like, or I'm the one that really stands out as being incompetent or incapable or not spiritual enough or not wise enough, what have you. (00:45)And that quote, I think it serves as a reminder of like my process of coming to belong in NA and in that community that's really important to me. But also that spark that happens when you begin to feel that sense of connectedness with others despite all the differences between one another. When we really listen and support one another and share with each other that slowly but surely, we begin to see a little of those people in ourselves and a little of who we are reflected back to us in them.

label: remembering
def: re·​mem·​ber·ing // retaining in one's memory so as to bring it to mind
pullout: And as soon as I saw his picture, even though his hair had changed, I knew exactly who he was. And I certainly remembered that story and it instantly made me understand my connection with Providence, with this community and the people that are in it.
transcript: (00:00)I thought about this for a while yesterday, and then this wonderful thing happened that made me really feel connected. And so I'll tell you what that thing was. I dropped a friend of mine off at the train station, and she and her little girl boarded a train to Connecticut. They noticed that there was a man—silver haired gentleman—who was smiling at them the entire time that they were waiting on the platform. And though this might be disgruntling to some, my friend Val, she's got a lot of angels protecting her, so she doesn't worry about those kinds of things. (00:41)And so they boarded the train, and Valerie and her little girl took their compartment. And the gentleman who had been smiling at them very grandfatherly passed them and said hello and smiled at them with these gorgeous eyes and kept on going a few compartments ahead and settled on a seat on the opposite side of them. (01:04)And a few minutes into the train ride, he came to them and said, "I noticed you're a member of RIBS, Rhode Island Black Storytellers." And Valerie, of course, said, "Yes, I am." And he said, "Do you know a gentleman by the name of Rochelle Coleman?" And she looked at the way he was smiling, and she said, "As a matter of fact, he just dropped me off." (01:28)And he began to tell her a story about a time that took place many years ago. We were both walking on Hope Street, and he was coming towards me, and I noticed that he was carrying this thing in his arm almost like a loaf of bread. And as we got closer and closer, I noticed that this was no loaf of bread. This was a baby. And the baby's head was in the palm of his hand. And the rest of the baby's body was straddling his forearm, almost like a waiter doing plate service, not carrying the plates on a tray, but just lined up on his arm, ready to deliver to a table. And the closer and closer these two got to me, the more I was just laughing, because this little baby was just enjoying this ride and giggling on this man's forearm, who had bright, smiling eyes and a shock of red hair. (02:39)Now, there was a car that was coming up behind him on Hope Street, and the car must have been as interested as I was in this scenario. And the windows rolled down, and these three boys—three young black boys—were watching this man carry this baby. And just as they passed him, three of the boys leaned out of the window and yelled, "Man, you don't have caring no baby." And he looked at me, and I looked at him. It was a little shocking, and I just started laughing because this was a funny little moment. And the man looked at me and he said, "I've carried all seven of my children in this way on these crisp fall evenings and to a tee, each one of them have enjoyed this." Well how do you argue with a man who's carried seven children that way? How do you argue with a man who's raised seven children? And how could you even question what they loved? (03:52)Well, I would say about five years later, I went into the John F. Kennedy School, not far from where we had talked that day, and he was the PTA President. We exchanged this memory of him carrying this baby like a loaf of bread or like a waiter doing arm service. And he showed me the little girl that was that little child that he'd been carrying. She had to be in about third or fourth grade at the time. And I've always remembered that. We've met several times since then, and we've always exchanged this memory. (04:33)And today on the train, talking to Val, he told her about this moment and the boys who had passed saying he didn't know what he was doing. Val thought that that was the funniest thing. And of course, she took a picture of him on the train and texted it to me. That man with the smiling eyes and shock of red hair, whose hair was now gray-white, but he still had those same smiling eyes. (05:11) And as soon as I saw his picture, even though his hair had changed, I knew exactly who he was. And I certainly remembered instantly that story of passing each other on Hope Street and the young boys telling him that he didn't know how to carry a baby. And instantly I started laughing. In the caption of his picture, he said that that little girl now had her own little girl. And it instantly made me understand my connection with Providence, with this community and the people that are in it.

label: resonance
def: res·​o·​nance // a synchronous gravitational relationship, so as to evoke a response
pullout: If I pick something up and the words or the language somehow creates a resonance with these ineffable feelings or thoughts, it's a very profound feeling of connection in that I don't feel so alone
transcript:
(00:00)I find that my reading choices are guided by my mood, and that's because when I read, sometimes there are emotions or feelings or thoughts that I don't quite have the language or the courage to examine. Reading sometimes helps suss that out. And it's usually with fiction or poetry. If I pick something up and the words or the language somehow creates a resonance with these ineffable feelings or thoughts, it's a very profound feeling of connection in that I don't feel so alone, that these very personal and very particular thoughts have been expressed or approximated by another person who published whatever it is I'm reading. (00:54)The first thing that comes to mind is Charlotte Bronte's Villette , which is one of my favorite books. And the main character, Lucy Snowe, the protagonist, is—she's not a cynic, she has a very hardened eye towards the world, and for that reason she's also very funny. But she has this quote. I'm gonna Google it because I don't know it exactly. It's like, "Love is not a potato." (01:21)Oh wait here: "No mockery in this world ever sounds to me so hollow as being told to cultivate happiness. What does such advice mean? Happiness is not a potato to be planted and mulled and tilled with manure. Happiness is glory shining far down upon us out of heaven." Well, I don't know about that, but I do like that she opens with, "No mockery in this world ever sounded to me so hollow as being told to cultivate happiness."

That's something that made me feel connected—I think these stories about these kind of hopeless, a little self-obsessed dreamers always resonates with me, and it helps to know that there have always been these sort of useless dreamers and writers throughout history.

label: reverie
def: rev·​er·​ie // the condition of being lost in thought
pullout: Ironically, I feel most connected—grounded is more apt a word, perhaps in my case—when I'm out on my own.
transcript: (00:00)Ironically, I feel most connected—grounded is more apt a word, perhaps in my case—when I'm out on my own, taking a walk, a hike or a drive by myself. Anything where I can get lost in my own reverie and thoughts. (00:19)Daydream, reflect and feel grounded.

label: rituals
def: rit·​u·​als //the established form for a ceremonial or choreographed act
pullout: I, a nearly 40-year-old woman, am there doing the same chants, the same expectations, throwing out the same insulting nicknames or the same endorsing nicknames for the people who are performing live in the ring—that has been a sense of shared ritual.
transcript: (00:00)Where I have felt recently as an adult, where I most belong, is where I would last, on paper, have expected to belong, which is in a group of wrestling fans watching a live wrestling performance, where I, a nearly 40-year-old woman, am there doing the same chants, the same expectations, throwing out the same insulting nicknames or the same endorsingnicknames for the people who are performing live in the ring. And realizing that we had the same expectations of who is a villain, who is a hero, who we want to win, who we know is going to win. (00:19)That kind of collective consciousness of the theater, of what is presented as to what is going to happen and what we all know, based on the narrative, is actually going to happen. That has made me feel like I am as much a part of the show as the woman or man in the ring. And knowing what to expect with the audience. (01:00)That has been a sense of shared choreography and shared ritual and that has been a sense of shared belonging.

label: routes
def: routes // established or selected courses of travel or action
pullout: And we all just went along on our route.
transcript: (00:00)A couple months ago, I was on a four train headed downtown from the Bronx when behind me, a man yells, "Hey, yo." And I turn around right as another man's throwing an empty water bottle at this guy who's laying on his side along the bench, just peeing into the middle of the train. (00:22)Pretty quickly, another woman stands up and responds to these two men saying, "Leave him alone. He doesn't know where he is, he doesn't know what he's doing." And they settled down; the man stopped peeing, and we all just went along our route.

label: safety
def: safe·​ty // the condition of being free from harm or risk
pullout: And I guess I felt really confident and safe and good because I was remembering all the great times I had with my family. But also because maybe it wouldn't happen again in my life.
transcript: (00:00)So I've been traveling in Cambodia with my family for many years, and on the last year, I traveled with one of my friends, and one day, I was waiting for him. So I had like a one full day by myself. And so it was in Siem Reap, which is like really well known because there are all the temples from Angkor—Angkor is the old city with all the old temples. I decided to spend the day in one of the temples that's my favorite place. I don't really know why it's my favorite place, but I spend all day there by myself, thinking of my life and listening to music and reading a book. (00:45) And I guess I felt really confident and safe and good because I was remembering all the great times I had with my family. But also because maybe it wouldn't happen again in my life. And so I remember this moment as like a unique moment. There are not many moments like that in your lifetime and I remember it really well even if it was ten years ago—and I guess because I felt connected with myself and I know that it was the right place at the right time and I didn't need anyone or anything to be happy at this particular moment. (01:20)This temple called Bayon which is a really famous place and it has changed a lot because it has become a more touristic place. And so in 2010—last time I went—I could really enjoy all the positive energy without too many tourists because it was low season. (01:36)I don't really know why I felt so connected with this particular temple because there are so many others. But at this temple, what is really well known is there are faces of old god smiling and the face of these gods represented everywhere in these temples make you feel like forgetting about everything else, you know, you are in a safe place and you are connected.

label: sameness
def: same·​ness // the quality or state of being without addition, change, or discontinuance
pullout: Whatever sameness I've noted in my relationship with women is not the sameness of women and certainly not the sameness of parts.
transcript: (00:00)But whatever sameness I've noted in my relationship with women is not the sameness of Woman and certainly not the sameness of parts. Rather it is the shared, crushing understanding of what it means to live in a patriarchy.

label: self-doubt
def: self·doubt // a feeling of doubt or uncertainty
pullout: I know I've had moments when I have felt like I've belonged, but do I generally belong?
transcript: (00:00)This is kind of tough. I mean, I know I've had moments when I have felt like I've belonged, but, like, do I generally belong? Is this something that I frequently experience? Not really. And I couldn't quite catch a hold of a specific moment. This was all on my mind a little bit. (00:21)And then Jocelyn and I walked to an event together last night, and I said, you know, I'm kind of struggling a little bit. I said, it sort of like, fostered a little bit of self-doubt, where I went, do I belong? Have I felt like I belong? And she was like, oh, my God, that's so weird. That was exactly how I felt. (00:46)So out of this conversation, we had this moment where we went like, oh, we sort of, like, found this point of commonality.

label: signs
def: signs // something material or external that stands for or signifies something spiritual
pullout: It might sound a little bit weird, but it kind of just felt like a sign from the universe.
transcript:
(00:00)A couple of months ago, I was on the subway back from work one evening and I saw a poem on the side of the train, like usually where various ads are displayed. And I really felt struck by that poem because it related a lot to how I was feeling at the time. My boyfriend and I were going through a bit of a rough patch because we both just had been working so much and basically just getting used to not really being able to spend as much time together during the week as we had been used when I was in law school and when he was at his old job. (00:32)The poem just resonated with me and made me feel happy and content, and not really as sad about the situation as I had been feeling. It might sound a little bit weird, but it kind of just felt like a sign from the universe. I kind of just connected in that moment and just had this feeling that things were going to work out and going to be okay.

Seeing it kind of right when I needed to see it made me feel content and grounded.

label: simultaneity
def: si·​mul·​ta·​neous // existing or occurring at the same time
pullout:
And I happen to be thinking 
about them 
at the same moment.
transcript: (00:00)Something that makes me feel connected, that I really love, is when somebody text me. Like I happen to be thinking about them at the same moment that they text me or reach out to me or show that they're thinking of me in some way. It's just such a nice feeling because it makes me feel tethered to another person. And it's even better when it's simultaneous. I love it.

label: soul
def: soul // the immaterial essence, animating principle, or actuating cause of an individual life
pullout: Place is a container of soul.
digtxt: An excerpt from "Gardens: An Essay on the Human Condition," by Robert Pogue Harrison
transcript:
(00:00)" In the fusion of place and soul. The soul is as much of a container of place as place is a container of soul."

This is a quote by Robert Pogue Harrison. It makes sense of an experience I had, which changed my perception of home and belonging. I used to associate home with a particular place, my childhood home that I grew up in. A couple years ago my parents moved from California to Utah. I felt nostalgic when my parents sent photos of the California house packed up. Upon visiting their new home in Utah, I walked into the living room. The light was pouring in through big windows, and I immediately felt at home. It was then that I realized that home was not tied to a specific place for me, but to emotion and atmosphere. And that realization was freeing.

label: sound
def: sound // a particular auditory impression
pullout: To me, music is maybe the most important of all the arts. Just because it's sound. God is sound.
transcript:
(00:00)Alright. I think this thing is on. You're gonna have to edit the shit out of this. Connected by sound, I would suppose, would be one of mine—through music. You know, with kind of the communal experience. To me, music is maybe the most important of all the arts. Just because it's sound. God is sound, you know. And there's all these different rhythms, crazy rhythms that are out there. Strange rhythms. (00:23)It can be electronic, it can be drums, whatever. So it's always been music. I mean, I love all of the arts, obviously, but fucking—I couldn't live without fucking music. You connect that with everything growing up, with friends, you know, identity about punk rock, different scenes and bebop—like throughout history, people have found their kind of tribe. (00:43)Grateful Dead is a great example. Me and my brother—that hit us.

I remember it really crystal clear. We're very young. I'm probably 21 with our good buddy and my brother. And we drive up and see the great Phil Lesch who was a bass player for the Grateful Dead. We're all too young, so we never saw Jerry. Jerry died. So we went up to this festival—and it's just seeing Phil playing all these tunes that we grew up to—"Fantastic on Broken Chain"—and just being there with my brother and our buddies and hanging out and camping and sleeping in a van and me buying beer. There was other stuff, obviously. It was a glorious weekend. Hanging out with older Heads I used to work with at one of my first college jobs who actually toured with the Dead, who was a Deadhead. Meeting him in the lot. (01:29)Like my uncle followed the Dead, my dad saw him in Missoula. The important thing to remember is there's concert. They had people—thank God, fucking God—people taped almost every show, predominantly. There's a lot of recorded stuff out there. So I couldn't listen to shows where my uncle was 15 and my dad was like 20, at some of their first shows because it's on tape. That's the preservation of art, which no one really thought of. They were like the first band to really—or the followers did it—and they tolerated it, kind of. And then there was a taper section. So you have all these shows—I can listen to shows that friends have been to, that older cats have been to. That's all preserved. And that's archival history right there.

label: spaces
def: spaces // a limited extent in one, two, or three dimensions
pullout: I'm feeling connection to a space. I walked into this apartment and it felt like a place that I could be or that I already had been.
transcript: (00:00)I'm walking through Greenpoint, and now Williamsburg. I have keys to an apartment. So at this moment, I'm feeling very connected to this place, to people around me, but also connection to a space. (00:16)I walked into this apartment and it felt like a place that I could be or that I already had been. And the people in the apartment that were greeting me there were friends and, you know, new and old Kendra being there and introducing me to the new friend and this new couple. So, yeah, I'm feeling connected and definitely a sense of belonging. Sometimes this city makes me feel, you know—the anonymity is something that I've always liked, but sometimes it's hard to grasp your place here. So right now, tonight, it's a little chilly. I'm walking. I'm gonna get off here. But I'm feeling connected.

label: sport
def: sport // physical activity engaged in for pleasure
pullout: We decided that we must have been the greatest rowers ever in the history of the world and in the history of the sport, because that day was pure magic.
transcript: (00:00)My longtime rowing partner and I were going out in Marina del Rey in a double skull for the first time since she was in recovery from cancer. The idea was we were going to see if we could get ourselves ready for the Head of the Charles Regatta, which is a three-mile race that takes place in Boston every year in October. Also, it's known as the largest Regatta in the world. Over ten thousand people participate over three days. Margie and I had rode in this event many times in the past and had won the race together and it was really our favorite event. (00:42)So we were going out for the first time, getting ready, and we had no idea what to expect because she was still recovering. We were quite familiar with each other in a boat, having rode together for more than 20 years and had been friends for a long time. Plus, both of us had been on the national rowing team, so we had techniques that were very similar. (01:09)So this could have been a row like any other. And normally when you get back in the boat after being away, it can feel unstable—a little rocky, a little rough. But this particular day was magic. Despite not being in the boat for over two years together and Margie still recovering her strength, you would have thought we had been practicing every single day. This outing was perhaps the most perfect rowing experience I've ever had in my 45 years in a sport. (01:41)We were completely in sync with one another, rowing like we were a single person. The boat was set up perfectly and we felt like we were absolutely flying. It was early in the morning, the sun had just come up, beautiful blue skies, and the water was like glass, so you could not have asked for better conditions. But unlike other times we had had in a boat, we barely said a word to one another until we reached the dock at the end of the outing about an hour later. (02:14)And in talking, we agreed. Number one: it was the best row we had ever had. We weren't sure exactly why. Maybe we were fooling ourselves because we hadn't been in the boat for a while and we were just so grateful to be there. But in the end, we decided that we must have been the greatest rowers ever in the history of the world and in the history of the sport, because that day was pure magic.

label: synchronicity
def: syn·​chro·​nic·​i·​ty // the coincidental occurrence of events, especially psychic ones
pullout: It feels like there's sort of this synchronous thought, like we're connected even when we go days or weeks without speaking.
transcript: (00:00)I think that one of the times I feel most connected is when I get this text from my cousin or I text her, and the response is always like, "Oh, my God, I was literally just thinking about you." And that sounds like such a cliche, but it's this real thing that we have somehow—we're different ends of the country. And I'll text her, and she's like, "I was just about to text you." Or she'll text me and I literally just had her in my mind. (00:25)So it feels like there's sort of this synchronous thought; it feels like we're connected even when we go days or weeks without speaking.

label: talks
def: talks // acts or instances in which ideas are expressed or exchanged by means of spoken words
pullout: And I think my response when I'm feeling overwhelmed is to talk with people. I always try to understand how they deal with their problems and doubts.
transcript: (00:00)I've been here in the US for almost a year now, and my first few months here were really hard in terms of adaptation and you know, lots of things going on. And being here for the first time was really intense. (00:19)And I think my response when I'm feeling overwhelmed is to talk with people. I always try to understand how they deal with their problems and doubts. So I did that, and I feel that I've been more, I don't know, more outgoing this semester, that I'm feeling better about myself. (00:42)So one of these talks that I had—we were talking precisely about feeling . . . you know how important it is to feel like you're part of something, to feel like you belong. It was such a sweet, endearing moment and she said something about it's very true that we truly care for each other. And that moment, it was just so cute. So every time that I'm feeling a little bit off, I think about how very heartwarming it is to feel part of this community and feel that I actually belong. Hearing that from someone else, it was just very nice.

label: time
def: time // the measurable period during which an action, process, or condition exists or continues
pullout: We were together during the years where we became the people we are today and it made me really happy to know that we'll always have those shared experiences.
transcript: (00:00)I recently had a chance to visit friends I haven't seen in a long time. There's always a small voice in my head wondering how hanging out will go. Like, Will it be awkward? Do we have things to talk about now? But as soon as I saw them, it felt like ten years ago, when we were college freshmen. (00:15) We were together during the years where we became the people we are today. And it made me really happy to know that we'll always have those shared experiences to remind us that we're forever connected, no matter how much time passes and no matter where we are in the world.

label: togetherness
def: to·​geth·​er // the state of being in contact, connection, or union with others, sometimes making up a larger whole
pullout: When you hear the music and you feel the crowd is enjoying it—this is the best feeling—when you're all together, dancing together.
transcript: (00:00)When you're in the crowd, especially when you're somewhere in the festival or in the club at the main stage, when you hear the music and you feel the crowd is enjoying it—this is the best feeling—when you're all together, dancing together. It's a feeling when you know where you are and you know how to behave and you have control over the situation, but at the same time, you're like a part of a big organism. (00:32)It's a rare feeling because a lot of times we are alone in our rooms when we work or when we go somewhere. Most of the time we are alone. But sometimes I think a human needs this kind of social interaction where you're a part of big community or big crowd.

label: tradition
def: tra·​di·​tion // an inherited, established, or customary pattern of behavior
pullout: And as they were collecting the water for the fountain, I remember standing in front of the church and just closing my eyes and feeling so at peace.
transcript: (00:00)It had been two years since I was able to go back to my home, which I consider Spain. And over the summer, I was fortunate enough to go back and spend some real time connecting with my roots and also connecting with a home that I've had a lot of problems identifying with because that's the constant going back and forth from Spain to the United States. (00:00)And there was one moment this summer where I was in Caamaño, which is where my mother grew up. It's a very small farm village and we go around every Sunday to this fuente, which is a—I don't remember what's it called; it's kind of like a fountain, but it comes out of the mountains. And we bring reusable bottles of water and we get the water from this fuente. (00:58)It was my father, my mother and I. And next to the fuente is this church where my mother's brother is buried. So it's tradition that we go get water, we give our grievances to her brother. And this time we're walking around the church, just looking around. It's been a while since we've all been there and we saw that there were some stairs to go on top of the church. So my father and I were, like, walking up the church. We're, like, now on top of the church where the bell is chiming and my mother is, like, so scared. My mom is, like, so scared because she hates heights and she's, like, yelling at us to come down. So we go down, but I take a little bit of time. (01:45)And as they were collecting the water for the fountain, I remember standing in front of the church for a couple of minutes and just closing my eyes and hearing the cows and the chickens and hearing the water run and hearing the cars pass by and feeling so at peace and so at home again. It was a moment that I was really able to connect back to my identity and also feel a lot of grief the last two years that I wasn't able to go back. And I think back to that moment a lot when I'm having hardships here in the States or I'm missing home.

label: transcendence
def: tran·​scen·​dence // qualities extending or lying beyond the limits of ordinary experience
pullout: How something so simple can be so transcending. I hadn’t felt that kind of beauty before in the company of strangers.
transcript: (00:00)I didn't ever grow up with a religion, but I wanted to sing Christmas Carols. And I was staying in the East Village and there's a church called Grace church—I think it's like almost 175 years old now, but I wanted to find a small church because I was by myself and I'd never done it before. But I thought, well, I'll just try and be in this company of strangers. And I walked in and sat down and I was really scared because I'd never done it before, let alone go to church. (00:39)But there was this really nice woman next to me. She helped me find where to start singing because I think she probably knew I'd never done it before anyway. So I'm singing, you know, all these different songs. And I remember the time we were just all in unison singing "A Silent Night."(01:05)And I feel like I'm going to cry right now because it was so beautiful, with the candles lit and all the people together singing. It was just probably the one of the most beautiful experiences I've ever had. And I was by myself. But I did feel connected to all these people and to the story and to this really nice woman who sat next to me. And she had, too, the most beautiful voice. I could just melt. I just remember stopping because I couldn't get through the song, because I started crying. (01:53)But to this day, it's like just one of the most incredible experiences I've ever had. And I really felt connected to just everything, to humanity and to the beauty of people and connected with myself and how something so simple can be so transcending. And I hadn't felt that kind of beauty before. You know, in the company of strangers, the sense of belonging was definitely part of that whole entire think.

label: trees
def: trees // woody perennial plants having a single, elongated main stem that branches out into others
pullout: I dug five holes and put five trees into those holes.
transcript: This is a hard question for me but I realize that last week I was up at my place in Oquossoc and I dug five holes and put five trees into those holes and just felt really connected to that place and also connected to the idea that Mavis and Melba, my granddaughters, would someday, hopefully enjoy some huge, spruce and fir trees spreading their wings so to speak over that very important piece of land.

label: trips
def: trips // intenses visionary experiences undergone by a person who has psychedelic drugs
pullout: I first tripped on acid when I was 16 at boarding school.
digtxt: Watch Michael Pollan's Documentary "How to Change Your Mind
transcript:
(00:00)One experience that made me feel connected was when I first tripped on acid when I was 16 at boarding school. I think I was 16—me and my best friend cut class and she had some acid and we took it and we just went in the woods all day. And it was the best, best day ever.

At that time I was very far from the happiest I’d ever been, though not the closest to the lowest either. I hadn’t intended to do anything that day. I convinced the nurse to give me a sick day—a get-out-of-class/barn-chores-free-day—because I wasn’t “feeling well.” And then I went on this trip (my first) very spontaneously. And I’m so glad and so thankful that things lined up the way they did that day because it permanently and fundamentally changed me. I was happier after. Obviously I was pretty happy during as well. Most notable to me was the new—or, more accurately, previously experienced but then foreign—sensation of belonging, of being included because I was included—because people wanted me to be and because I wanted to be. I've never really felt disconnected from nature, though it should be noted that nature was a big element of the whole experience for me.
